content.webTitle: James Dasaolu and Tiffany Porter dash to European gold in Zurich

fields.headline: James Dasaolu and Tiffany Porter dash to European gold in Zurich
fields.bodyText: Perhaps the most reassuring sound to British ears after James Dasaolu finally added a major title to his sub-10 second times by winning 100m gold at these European Championships was that he was not entirely satisfied. “Of course winning a medal is going to give me confidence but I’m under no illusion that there are guys out there running 9.8 and 9.9sec on a regular basis,” he said. “There is still work to be done to improve me as an athlete.” Dasaolu’s winning time of 10.06 on a cold and blustery night in Zurich, ahead of the Frenchman Christophe Lemaître, who claimed silver in 10.13, and Harry Aikines-Aryeetey, who took bronze in 10.22, was nothing special but he will not care a jot. He answered the question marks about whether his fragile tendons could get through the rounds to become the first Briton since Darren Campbell in 1998 to win a major 100m title. “I’d have loved to have gone quicker but the championships are all about executing your race,” he said. “In the build-up we had delays and faulty starts so it was about concentrating. I didn’t think I got the best of starts and I actually thought I messed up my opportunity of even picking up a medal but once I got through my drive phase I was able to pull away.” Dasaolu was helped by the absence of another Frenchman, Jimmy Vicaut – the fastest man in Europe this season – who pulled out before the semi-finals with a thigh injury. But as Dasaolu pointed out afterwards, he has had struggles to overcome too. “I wasn’t sure if I was going to be here at the beginning of the year,” he said. “The weather wasn’t the best and we were delayed by half an hour but I zoned out and focused on the job in hand.” And there was further glory for British sprinters as Tiffany Porter also won gold in the women’s 100m hurdles. She was ahead at the start and, though the French athlete Cindy Billaud came dangerously close to pipping her on the dip, Porter held on to win in 12.76 sec, with Billaud second in 12.79 and Cindy Roleder of Germany third in 12.82. Porter, who was born in Michigan but has a British mother, said: “This is my first gold medal so I couldn’t be happier. I had a great start but the rest of my race wasn’t great. But it’s really important to stay composed and execute the 10 hurdles to the best of your ability.” There was more unexpected success for Britain in the women’s 100m as Ashleigh Nelson won bronze behind the brilliant Dutch heptathlete Dafne Schippers, who is gunning for the 100m and 200m double at these Championships. But while Schippers, who won world championship bronze in the heptathlon last year and was the pre-race favourite, looked merely relieved to win in 11.12 sec – an impressive time given the spitting rain and a strong headwind of -1.7m – Nelson was utterly elated. The 23-year-old from Stoke, who describes herself as a tomboy who loves make-up and fashion, was not expected to feature in the medals but showed her potential with a personal best of 11.19sec in the heats and backed it up in the final to become the first British 100m sprint medallist at the European championships since Andrea Lynch in 1974. “The last few years have just been managing injuries and it’s been tough,” said Nelson. “This year I wanted to come back and make sure I was in the final here because when you’re in it you never know what might happen.” “I didn’t feel like that was my best race and I feel like there’s a lot more to come. It’s taken a lot of persistence and belief from myself and the people around me. I can’t thank everyone enough.” Earlier in the night Conrad Williams, Martin Rooney and Matthew Hudson-Smith all progressed through to ’s men’s 400m final by winning their semi-finals. But Christine Ohuruogu was made to puff a little more than she would have liked in qualifying for the final of the women’s 400m in a modest 52.66sec – more than a second slower than her opening round on Tuesday and behind the Spaniard Indira Terrero.
